history.content: A google search for something like "eecs hss requirement Berkeley" will answer this question for you. In future, please do your own research before posting.

children.subject:
Hi Anon, 


These are created by the College of Letters & Sciences for their general education requirements. Unfortunately, we don't receive any additional training on them. As each list of the six lists has hundreds of courses, we definitely don't know them all. I think the courses they list are courses that are currently approved to fulfill their breadth requirements, not necessarily those that are offered during the term specified. I would cross-check those that you find on the list with schedule.berkeley.edu. 

In regards to OP's question, I think it's doubtful that a statistics course will fit under one of those breadth categories, unless it's directly related to humanities or social sciences (ie. how to teach statistics to high school students). 

Best,

Nicole
My guess is that CogSci C131 is too technical for a humanities/social science courses.

With all due respect to the instructor's answer, a google search does lead you to a series of Excel Documents listing the Humanities/SS

courses that will fulfill the requirements.  The documents seem to specify the allowable courses by department, number and semester which is really helpful.

But honestly, I have had difficulty using the documents.  For example, there are courses listed for Spring and Summer 2018 that I cannot find on the Berkeley Class Schedule.  For example, I found Statistics C79 on the allowable (Social Science) list for Spring/Summer Semesters 2018 but I cannot find it in the Class Schedule.  Conversely, I considered taking Cog Sci 131 which I thought should fulfill the requirement but it is not on the list.  Perhaps I am not understanding how to use the system?  

Any additional guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you

As a student, I did not take the response as sassy at all.  In my opinion, this Piazza can get flooded with lazy questions that could be answered with quick online searches.  Kindly reminding students about this phenomenon, rather than encouraging this behavior, can hopefully help keep this Piazza clean and easier to use for instructors and students alike.
Why not both? "We don't receive any additional training on them" in addition to the formal answer would have been better, and easily come across as less sassy.

My apologies if my original response came across as sassy. I was aiming for "give a student a fish and you feed them for a day; teach a student to fish and you feed them for a lifetime", not just being unhelpful.

history.content: Would Statistics courses satisfy the H/SS requirement?
history.subject: Eligible H/SS Courses
